Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: It is time for the daily morning prayer service in the main chapel, as scheduled in the convent's regular order of the day.
Story: I stood at the bench, gavel in hand, my voice steady as I explained the jury instructions. Suddenly, my clerk slipped me a note—urgent, in bold. The Supreme Court had just overturned the very precedent I was referencing. My mind raced. I knew I had to halt the proceedings, review the new ruling, and ensure justice was served according to the latest law. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart clenched. The chapel bell was ringing; it was time for morning prayers. As a nun, I was expected to be present, to join my sisters in devotion, to uphold the discipline of our sacred routine. The weight of both worlds pressed on me—my duty to the law, to the people in this courtroom, and my commitment to God, to the quiet sanctuary of prayer. I felt torn, standing between the demands of justice and the call to spiritual obedience, uncertain which path to follow in this moment.
